steps.title: Remove the papery husks from each tomatillo.
steps.content: Remove the papery husks from each tomatillo. Discard any tomatillos that are past their prime (yellowed, brown, split, discolored). Wash any dirt or other grime off them; you will need to be especially concerned to remove any "stickiness" on the peel.<

steps.title: Leave the tomatillos to dry.
steps.content: Leave the tomatillos to dry. The tomatillos should only be placed in the freezer dry, not wet.

steps.title: Arrange parchment paper on a baking sheet that has a rim.
steps.content: Arrange parchment paper on a baking sheet that has a rim. Place the dry tomatillos across the baking sheet. [2] X Research source It is up to you whether you freeze the tomatillos whole or sliced.

steps.title: Put into the freezer and allow to freeze.
steps.content: Put into the freezer and allow to freeze.

steps.title: Remove the sheet from the freezer once the tomatillos are frozen.
steps.content: Remove the sheet from the freezer once the tomatillos are frozen. They are now ready to be packed into small freezer bag lots. [3] X Research source Their pre-frozen state will ensure that they do not stick together in the bags.

steps.title: Seal each bag tightly.
steps.content: Seal each bag tightly. It is recommended that you remove as much air as possible from the bag. [4] X Research source Label and date so that you know when you placed them in the freezer.

steps.title: Use as required.
steps.content: Use as required. Allow to thaw and use in salsa and soup. Note that they will be a little softer in texture than prior to freezing but are still perfectly edible; just prefer recipes that require mushier tomatillos.
